4. So let us now establish in an ordered manner,
under the correct circumstances,
precise rules and fixed Laws,
which, through observing many aspects,
Nature has wisely revealed to us,
lest we unknowingly approach
some system of poses outside of
exact measurements, rules and statutes.
right-middleNature teaches and sets good laws.

5. To place a standing figure, we must
draw a straight line, like a plumbline,
downward from the top.
This shall be like the string of a bow
set against the outward curve of the body
and shall descend from the pit at the throat
to the center of the weight-bearing foot.
Thus may we solidly construct a standing figure.
right-middleHow one should place a figure.

6. For observe: a person and a column
are comparable in stance and composition;
and since head as the heaviest part
is supported by the body, it is fitting
that the foot be placed underneath it as a Base,
and therefore the weight-bearing foot
carries the head so perfectly
that one can set a plumbline between the two.
right-middleA person compared to a column

7. This perpendicular line
or vertical stroke that I mention
I do not find, in fact, necessary to draw,
lest one become timid while drawing -
but one should imagine it,
and determine it securely
so that the base of the neck, as if on a plumbline,
aligns precisely with the center of the foot, which carries the body.

8. For the head can move or bend toward one shoulder
or the other, which is sometimes appropriate;
but head and body must be placed in opposition
to one another, or –to put it more clearly–
the point is that one should carefully avoid
hanging the head on the same side
that one lets the body hang or bend.
right-middleMeasuring the height of the body along a plumbline of the body’s center.

9. The weight-bearing foot, together with the leg,
may extend forward, for a pleasant effect,
but there is a natural phenomenon
to consider, which is not only common
in people but in four-footed animals:
the right front leg and the rear left leg
must lift, step and fall together,
right-middle How a figure should move.
